I think what's missing from this discussion is the effect of 
selection.  Selection will have different effects in different 
domains.  Therefore, it is possible in one domain that those that do 
better tend to be simpler because of some property of the fitness 
function (i.e. the domain) and therefore the complexity will go 
down, whereas in a more difficult domain only more complex 
individuals are able to improve fitness and therefore complexity 
will go up.  In other words, the direction that complexity moves is 
not completely determined by the parameters or rates of adding 
structure.

That said, to me most of what Colin is saying makes sense.  His 
explanation of why fitness would drop makes sense too.  Of course, 
it depends on what you do if the top species is stagnating.  In my 
NEAT implementation, I decided that if the best species is 
stagnating that instead of deleting it I would delete all except the 
top 2 species so I could "zoom in" and focus on them, but what Colin 
is doing is removing the top species if it hasn't improved for some 
time, which is certainly valid, and would result in a drop in 
fitness if all the other species are stagnant as well.

ken

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Derek James <djames@g...> wrote:
> On Thu, 19 Aug 2004 22:05:44 +0100, Colin Green <cgreen@d...> 
wrote:
> > Yes the parameters are all correct and I agree that it seems 
counter
> > intuitive. Actually I think you answered this question yourself 
in your
> > response to John -  crossover. 
> 
> Well, this still doesn't make sense to me.  How are you handling
> crossover?  ANJI works as the original NEAT paper described--when 
two
> individuals mate, the topology of the fitter individual is used, 
while
> weight values for common connections have a 50/50 chance of coming
> from either parent.
> 
> Even if you're handling it another way, it still doesn't seem to 
make
> sense.  Our mutation rates for blended runs for Tic-Tac-Toe were :
> 
> add neuron: 0.005
> add connection: 0.01
> remove connection: 0.02
> 
> They were roughly balanced, and as a consquence, the average
> complexity for most runs remained steady.
> 
> Your subtractive mutation rates were triple your additive ones, so
> average complexity should be decreasing each generation.  Does your
> method of crossover always take the topology of the more complex
> individual or something?
> 
> > I truly beleive that this is down to species culling, and the 
phased
> > search graph backs up the idea. SharpNEAT employs elitism at the 
species
> > level, that is, each species' keeps at least it's 1 best genome 
and in
> > the experiments actually kept the best 20%,.
> 
> I'm sorry...I still don't understand the explanation.  But if 
you're
> using Ken's basic NEAT implementation and population fitness is
> steadily *decreasing* throughout the run, it certainly seems that
> something is wrong.
> 
> Ken?  Have you looked at the fitness graphs on Colin's page?  Does
> this make sense to you?
> 
> > Have a look back in the archives, I think species culling was 
discussed
> > some time ago when I poitned out that quite often a jump in 
fitness can
> > be seen shortly after culling the fittest species. 
> 
> Yeah, I remember the discussion and thought it made sense at the 
time
> as a way of enhancing the performance of a run.  I don't see how it
> should be *degrading* the performance of traditional or blended 
NEAT.
> 
> Derek
